children.name: endure b2
children.definition: endure/ɪnˈdjʊəʳǁɪnˈdʊər/  especiallywrittento experience pain or have difficult or unpleasant experiences over a long period - use this especially about people who are brave and patient :
examples: ▪ she has endured ten years of painful back operations.
▪ they were lost in the mountains for ten days, enduring hunger, thirst, and intense cold.

children.name: go through b2
children.definition: go through/ˈgəʊ θruː/  to experience a lot of problems in your life over a long period of time:
examples: ▪ peter had lost his job, and the family was going through a very difficult time.
▪ it’s good to see patrick looking so happy now, after all he’s gone through in the last few years.
go throughsthphrasal verbexperiencechịu đựngthấu qua
to experience a difficult or unpleasant situation
_i've been going through a bad patch recently.
_you'd think his children would be more sympathetic towards himafter allhe's gone through (= the many bad things he has experienced) .

children.name: undergo c1
children.definition: undergo/ˌʌndəʳˈgəʊ/  to experience a very difficult or unpleasant situation that you have no control over and cannot stop:
examples: ▪ the hostages were eventually released after undergoing a terrifying ordeal.
▪ he underwent major heart surgery last year.
▪ at that time she was undergoing tremendous emotional problems following the breakup of her marriage.
undergoverb[ t ] chịu đựng, trải quaundergoing,underwent,undergone
to experience something which is unpleasant or which involves a change
_she underwent an operation on a tumour in her left lung last year.
_cinema inbritainis undergoing a revival of popularity.

children.name: be subjected to c1
children.definition: be subjected to/biː səbˈdʒektd tuː/  to be forced to experience something very unpleasant, such as unfair or violent treatment, especially over a long time:
examples: ▪ black people in the area are claiming they have been subjected to repeated racial attacks from police officers.
▪ the charity helps children who have been subjected to domestic violence and sexual abuse.
be subject tosth
to have or experience a particular thing, especially something unpleasant
_cars are subject to a high domestic tax.
_in recent years, she has been subject to attacks of depression.

children.name: be in the grip of x
children.definition: be in the grip of/biː ɪn ðə ˈgrɪp ɒv/  to be experiencing an extremely unpleasant or serious situation that you have no control over and cannot stop:
examples: ▪ the sudan was in the grip of its worst famine for 20 years.
▪ much of europe was in the grip of postwar recession.
be in the grip ofsth
to be experiencing something unpleasant that you have no control over
_the country is currently in the grip of the worst recession for twenty years.

children.name: suffer b1 or b2
children.definition: suffer/ˈsʌfəʳ/  to experience physical or emotional pain when something bad happens to you:
examples: ( only emotional )
▪ children always suffer when their parents get divorced.
▪ in all wars, it’s innocent civilians who suffer most.
▪ anne still suffers a lot of pain in her leg.
suffer from
▪ two hundred million people worldwide suffer from parasitic diseases.
sufferverbfeel pain đau; đau khổ; bị
[ i ] to experience physical or mental pain
_i think he suffered quite a lot when his wife left him.
_she suffers terribly in the winter when it's cold and her joints get stiff.
_she's been sufferingfrom(= been ill with) cancer for two years.
_johnny suffersfrom(= is often ill with) asthma.
_if you're not happy with it, you should complain. don't just sufferin silence(= without saying anything) .
sufferverbexperience trải qua hoặc chịu
[ i or t ] to experience or show the effects of something bad
_the democrats suffered a crushing defeat in the last election.
_twenty-five policemen suffered minor injuries during the protest.
_the city suffered anotherblowlast month with the closure of the local car factory.
_if you will insist on eating three helpings of dessert,
i'm afraid you'll have to sufferthe consequences!
_[ + object + -ing verb ]i had to suffer her father moaningfor half an hour on the phone last night!
_when you're working such long hours, it's inevitable that your marriage will start to suffer.
_like a lot of his films, it suffersfrombeing a bit too long.

children.name: be in the throes of x
children.definition: be in the throes of/biː ɪn ðə ˈθrəʊz ɒv/  to be experiencing a difficult or unpleasant situation, especially one that continues a long time:
examples: ▪ kramer was in the throes of clinical depression and left the band for a while.
▪ in the throes of the great depression, franklin roosevelt developed the economic plan called ‘the new deal’.
in the throes ofsth
experiencing or doing something which is difficult, unpleasant or painful
the country is presently in the throes of the worst recession since the second world war.
he's in the throes of a mid-life crisis which makes him rather difficult to live with.

children.name: victim b2
children.definition: victim sb or sth which has been hurt, damaged or killed or has suffered : nạn nhân
examples: to provide financial aid to hurricane/flood, etc. victims
they are launching a massive aid program to help the famine victims.
victim of
victims of domestic abuse
we appear to have been the victimsofa cruel practical joke.
our local hospital has become the latest victimofthe cuts in government spending.

children.name: casualty x
children.definition: casualty/ˈkæʒuəlti/  someone who suffers as a result of an event or situation over which they have no control - used especially innewsreports:
examples: nạn nhân ( mentally )
▪ the corruption scandal has claimed yet another casualty: the finance minister, who was forced to resign last night.
casualty of
▪ the company is the latest casualty of the worldwide recession.
casualtynounbadly affected
[ c ] a person or thing that suffers as a result of something else happening
_she lost her job in 1989, a casualtyofthe recession.
_the first casualtyofthe reorganization will be the bus service, which will be stopped altogether.

children.name: target c1
children.definition: target/ ˈtɑː.ɡɪt / / ˈtɑːr- /   one or more people who are criticized or laughed at, or who experience unpleasant treatment from others :
examples: the prime minister is a favourite target of comedians.
target of
recently she has been the target of a series of obscene phone calls.

children.name: sth painful or unpleasant that you suffer
suffering b2
children.definition: suffering/ˈsʌfərɪŋ/  very unpleasant, painful, or upsetting conditions - use this especially about a situation that affectsa lot of people:
examples: ▪ the earthquake has caused massive damage and a great deal of human suffering.
▪ reporters described the suffering they had seen in the war zone.
sufferingnoun[ c or u ]nỗiđau(only mental )
when you experience physical or mental pain
_the war will cause widespread human suffering.

children.name: hardship c1
children.definition: hardship/ˈhɑːʳdʃɪp/  when your life is difficult and uncomfortable, especially because you are very poor:
examples: gian khổ , sóng gió ( đặc biệt do nghèo đói )
▪ during the war we faced many hardships.
▪ rising food prices caused great hardship for most of the population.
▪ many students suffer financial hardship.
hardshipnoun[ c or u ]
(something which causes) difficult or unpleasant conditions of life, or an example of this
economic hardship

children.name: plight c2
children.definition: plight/plaɪt/  a difficult and unpleasant situation, in which people are suffering a lot and that makes you feel great sympathy for them:
examples: ▪ the film deals with the nomadic desert people of the sahel, whose plight has worsened in the recent years of drought.
▪ a new report exposes the plight of skilled nurses, who work long hours for very low rates of pay.
plightnoun[ s ]hoàn cảnh khó khăn, cảnh ngộ khốn khổ
an unpleasant condition, especially a serious, sad or difficult one
_theplightofthe poor/homeless
_few of us can be unmoved by the plight of the romanian orphans.

children.name: agony x
children.definition: agony/ˈægəni/  a very sad, difficult, and unpleasant situation in which people suffer a lot, especially over a long time:
examples: ▪ in the book she describes the agony of watching her child die.
▪ with renewed fighting for control of the capital, there seems to be no end to the region’s agony.
agonynoun[ c or u ](sự)đau đớn cực độ về thể xác hoặc tinh thần
extreme physical or mental pain or suffering
_she lay there screaminginagony.
_i wasinan agonyofsuspense.
_we've bothsufferedagoniesofguilt over what happened.

children.name: torment x
children.definition: torment/ˈtɔːʳment/ severemental suffering, often continuing for a long time:
examples: ▪ she suffered years of private torment over her decision to have her children adopted.
▪ it’s difficult for us to understand the torment the hostages are going through.
tormentnounsự đau khổ
[ u ] great mental suffering and unhappiness, or great physical pain
_the family said they hadenduredyears of torment
and abuse at the hands of the neighbours.
_waiting for the result of the medical tests was sheer torment.
_he spent the nightintorment,trying to decide what was the best thing to do.

children.name: adversity x
children.definition: adversity/ədˈvɜːʳsɪti, ədˈvɜːʳsəti/  written a situation in which you have continuing difficulties that seem to be caused by bad luck:
examples: ▪ they have suffered more than their fair share of adversity and managed to overcome it every time.
in the face of adversitywhen experiencing adversity
▪ she somehow manages to keep laughing in the face of adversity.
adversitynoun[ c or u ]
a difficult or unlucky situation or event
she was always cheerfulinadversity.
the road to happiness is paved with adversities.

children.name: to suffer because of bad things you have done or mistakes you have made
suffer b2
children.definition: suffer/ˈsʌfəʳ/
examples: ▪ if you tell lies, it is you who will suffer in the end.
make somebody suffer
▪ when his mother caught him cheating she really made him suffer.
suffer for
▪ all over the world, people are suffering for their political or religious beliefs.
▪ i shouldn’t have drunk all that wine - i’ll suffer for it tomorrow morning.

children.name: count the cost x
children.definition: count the cost/ˌkaʊnt ðə ˈkɒstǁ-ˈkɔːst/ britishto suffer or start having problems as a result of mistakes or decisions you made at an earlier time:
examples: ▪ the school overspent on its budget last year, and now it’s having to count the cost.
count the cost of
▪ we are now counting the cost of our earlier mistakes.
count the cost
to start to understand how badly something has affected you
_i didn't read the contract fully before i signed it but i'm counting the cost now.

children.name: cost sb dearly/dear x
children.definition: cost somebody dearly/dear/ˌkɒst somebody ˈdɪəʳli, ˈdɪəʳǁˌkɔːst-/  if a mistake costs someone dearly or costs someone dear, they suffer a great deal because of it:
examples: ▪ this scandal could cost the government dearly.
▪ it was only a small mistake, but it cost us very dear.
costsbdear
if something that someone does, especially something stupid, costs them dear, it causes them a lot of problems
_later that year he attacked a photographer, an incident that cost him dear.

children.name: know/find out to your cost b2
children.definition: know/find out to your cost/ˌnəʊ, ˌfaɪnd aʊt tə jɔːʳ ˈkɒstǁ-ˈkɔːst/  if you know or find out something to your cost, you realize that something that happened or something you did at an earlier time is now causing problems or is likely to cause problems in the future:
examples: ▪ as we now know to our cost, the disease is highly contagious.
▪ many people have found out to their cost that insurance policies do not always cover damage from flooding.
costnounthing givencáigiá
[ s or u ] something which is given, needed or lost in order to get a particular thing
_we were going to paint the house ourselves, but when we considered the costintime and effort, we decided to get a painter to do it for us.
_the driver managed not to hit the child who ran in front of his car, but onlyat thecostofinjuring himself.
_she has finally got the job she wanted, butatgreat personal cost (= she has had to give up other things that were important to her) .
_it's not worth getting into an argument with tim, as i learnedtomy cost (= from my unpleasant experience of having done so) .

children.name: pay u
children.definition: pay/peɪ/  to have a bad experience as a way of being punished for something bad that you have done, mistakes you have made etc:
examples: pay for
▪ miller refused to testify and paid for it by being labelled a communist.
make somebody pay
▪ they think i’ve forgotten what they did to me, but i’ll make them pay.
pay dearly
▪ she drank far too much at the party and paid dearly for it the next day.
pay the price/the penalty
▪ tony didn’t do any studying all year but paid the price when it came to the exams.
pay forsthc2phrasal verb trả giá (lỗi lầm)
to be punished for doing something bad to someone else, or to suffer because of amistake that you made
_we all pay for our mistakes in some way at some time.
_he tricked me and i'm going to make him pay for it!
pay the pricec2: trả giá
to experience the bad result of something you have done
_if you abuse your body now,you'll pay the price when you're older.
pay dearly
to suffer a lot as a result of a particular action or event
_if you refuse to cooperate with us, you will pay dearlyforit.

children.name: at a/some cost to b2
children.definition: at a/some cost to/ət ə, sʌm ˈkɒst tuːǁ-ˈkɔːst-/  if you do something at a cost to someone or something, that person suffers because you do it:
examples: ▪ she’s struggled to keep the family going on her own -- at considerable cost to herself
.▪ ms gideon has defended her cause at great cost to her personal and political reputation.
costnounthing givencáigiá
[ s or u ] something which is given, needed or lost in order to get a particular thing
_we were going to paint the house ourselves, but when we considered the costintime and effort, we decided to get a painter to do it for us.
_the driver managed not to hit the child who ran in front of his car, but onlyat thecostofinjuring himself.
_she has finally got the job she wanted, butatgreat personal cost (= she has had to give up other things that were important to her) .
_it's not worth getting into an argument with tim, as i learnedtomy cost (= from my unpleasant experience of having done so) .

children.name: sb who seems to enjoy suffering
masochist x
children.definition: masochist/ˈmæsəkɪst/
examples: người thích chịu khổ
▪ he goes swimming in the sea in the middle of winter -- he must be some kind of masochist.
masochistic/ˌmæsəˈkɪstɪk◂/ [adjective]
▪ she seems to derive an almost masochistic pleasure from going out with men who treat her badly.

children.name: be a glutton for punishment x
children.definition: be a glutton for punishment/biː ə ˌglʌtn fəʳ ˈpʌnɪʃmənt/  use thishumorouslyabout someone who seems to like being put in situations where they will suffer, when it could have been avoided:
examples: ▪ being a glutton for punishment, i agreed to organize yet another children’s birthday party.
be a glutton for punishment
to be someone who seems to enjoy doing something that you consider unpleasant
_he's a real glutton for punishment, taking on all that extra work without getting paid for it.

children.name: martyr x
children.definition: martyr/ˈmɑːʳtəʳ/  someone who enjoys suffering because they make other people feel guilty about it, and therefore get sympathy and attention:
examples: ▪ don’t be a martyr - ask for help if you need it.
play the martyrbehave like one
▪ we all like to play the martyr sometimes.

children.name: be/fall prey to sth c2
children.definition: be/fall prey tosth

children.name: incur c2
children.definition: incurverb-rr-slightly formal chịu, gánh, mắc
examples: to experience something, usually something unpleasant, as a result of actions you have taken
_to incur debts/fines/bills
_the play has incurredthe wrath/angerof both audiences and critics.
_please detail anycosts/expensesincurred by you in attending the interview.

children.name: be consumed by/with sth c2
children.definition: be consumed by/withsth héo hon vì
examples: to have so much of a feeling that it affects everything you do
_he was consumed with jealousy.
_as a teenager, i was consumed by passion for the boy next door.

children.name: run up against sth c2
children.definition: run up againststhphrasal verbchạm trán; đụng độ; đối mặt
examples: to experience an unexpected difficulty
_the community centre scheme has run up against strong local opposition.

children.name: cost b2
children.definition: costnounthing givencáigiá
examples: [ s or u ] something which is given, needed or lost in order to get a particular thing
_we were going to paint the house ourselves, but when we considered the costintime and effort, we decided to get a painter to do it for us.
_the driver managed not to hit the child who ran in front of his car, but onlyat thecostofinjuring himself.
_she has finally got the job she wanted, butatgreat personal cost (= she has had to give up other things that were important to her) .
_it's not worth getting into an argument with tim, as i learnedtomy cost (= from my unpleasant experience of having done so) .
